Sadly, this is a rather big step back from the excellent 7 Wonders Duel. While the map adds a wee amount of area control as one of three possible victory conditions, some core elements from 7 Wonders Duel were dropped, perhaps, to make this game even more suitable as a gateway game or 'family friendly'. It is no longer possible to increase the resource cost to play cards for other players and the resources are all worth the same (in 7 Wonders Duel two resources were scarcer and more valuable than the others). Also, in Duel for Middle-Earth you have less control over your gold income, as it cannot be increased the same way as in its predecessor. Despite of the three possible victory conditions, gameplay has become a lot simpler and more luck-dependent. In other words, the decision space for players has become smaller.

The race track is merely a gimmicky effect (with shoddy execution), for which two pawns on the same track on the map would have sufficed.
Ultimately, the execution of the theme is disappointing. The visuals are, at best, mediocre, they resemble clichéd and interchangeable fantasy stereotypes (the depiction of Gollum for example suggests a blend between a gremlin and a monkey and most of the depicted scenes on the cards do not even hint at the many pivotal moments in the original Lord of the Rings books, but are very often reminiscent of... nothing).

The game seems cheaply produced, from the impractical insert that with some copies causes lid lift, the unusual (small) card size or the aforementioned race track.

All in all, this game is a worse reimplementation of a great game, cheaply produced and overhyped, mainly due to the all-time popular theme.

Why I culled it (Oct. 2024): Big disappointment for me given the pedigree. Unfortunately, I found that the streamlining in this game took away most of what I love about 7WD--the economy. That’s where much of the depth of 7WD lies, maneuvering over resources, making things more expensive for your opponent, and building up an engine. Although many of the mechanics of 7WD are present, there’s little engine-building in Duel for Middle-Earth. I did enjoy the area control map, and would be interested to see that incorporated into a 7WD expansion. I can see they were going for a lighter experience to suit the IP that just isn't for me.

The game ramps up in tension from round to round, often leading to a cinematic ending that will leave you wanting another go.
